properties.instruction:

be caught on the water in a thunderstorm.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued July 3 at 4:09PM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
properties.description:
* The warm air temperatures this 4th of July weekend in the upper 80s
to around 90 may cause people to underestimate the dangers of the
cold water temperatures which are currently only in the upper 50s
and 60s on the lakes and in the lower 70s on the rivers.

* The cold water temperatures can quickly cause hypothermia to
anyone immersed in the water. According to the Maine Warden
Service, when the water temperature is below 60 degrees, the
average submerged person could lose dexterity within minutes and
be unable to accomplish simple tasks. Anyone on small boats,
canoes or kayaks should plan accordingly if recreating this
weekend and use extreme caution to avoid this threat. Paddle
smart from the start and always wear your life jacket!

NWSheadline: National Weather Service Cold Water Safety Message

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued July 3 at 2:03PM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
properties.description:
Gore Creek at Vail affecting Eagle County

.High flows continue to move down Gore Creek as the warm
temperatures have accelerated the high elevation snowpack. Gore
Creek will hover near bankful over the next few days but forecasts
suggest a general decline in river levels through the weekend. Minor
lowland flooding is still a risk.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Gore Creek at Vail
* until further notice.
* At 01 PM Wednesday the stage was 8.8 feet.
* Bankfull stage is 9.2 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.2 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 9.5 feet early Thursday
morning.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Caution is urged when walking near waterways. Avoid
flooded areas and unstable riverbanks. Stay tuned to developments by
listening to NOAA Weather Radio or your local TV or radio stations.

Additional information can also be found on the NWS Grand Junction
homepage at weather.gov/gjt

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued July 3 at 3:58PM EDT until July 3 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Jacksonville FL
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Jacksonville has issued a Heat
Advisory, which is in effect from 11 AM to 6 PM EDT Thursday.

* HEAT INDEX VALUES...Up to 109 due to temperatures in the upper
90s, and dewpoints in the lower to mid 70s.

* TIMING...Late morning through late afternoon hours.

* IMPACTS...The heat and humidity may cause heat stress during
outdoor exertion or extended exposure.
properties.instruction:
A Heat Advisory is issued when the combination of hot temperatures
and high humidities creates heat indices of 108 degrees or higher.
The heat index is a measure of how hot it feels when the effect
of humidity combine with the temperature. High heat index values
can create dangerously hot conditions where individuals may become
critically exhausted if outdoors. Drink plenty of fluids, stay in
an air-conditioning if possible, remain out of the sun, and check
on relatives and neighbors who may be sensitive to heat related
illnesses. Anyone overcome by heat should be moved to a cool and
shaded location. Heat stroke is an emergency, call 911.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued July 3 at 1:48PM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
properties.description:
Eagle River near Gypsum affecting Eagle County

.Warm temperatures continue to accelerate high elevation runoff.
This runoff will cause the Eagle River to run high and fast and
to slightly above bankfull  stage. minor low land flooding is
expected along the Eagle River near Gypsum. A slow decrease in river
levels is anticipated late this week into the weekend.
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Eagle River near Gypsum
* until further notice.
* At 01 PM Wednesday the stage was 8.2 feet.
* Bankfull stage is 7.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 9.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will rise to near 8.3 feet by Thursday
morning.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Safety Message...Caution is urged when walking near waterways. Avoid
flooded areas and unstable riverbanks. Stay tuned to developments by
listening to NOAA Weather Radio or your local TV or radio stations.

Additional information can also be found on the NWS Grand Junction
homepage at weather.gov/gjt

properties.headline: Flash Flood Watch issued July 3 at 1:46PM MDT until July 4 at 6:00AM MDT by NWS Rapid City SD
properties.description:
Soils across the area are saturated due to recent above normal
rainfall, and the atmosphere is very moist. With additional
thunderstorms expected this afternoon into tonight, there is a
potential for flash flooding.
The Flash Flood Watch continues for

* Portions of South Dakota and Wyoming, including the following
areas, in South Dakota, Butte, Harding, Perkins, Ziebach, the
Northern Black Hills, the Northern Foot Hills, the Northern
Meade County Plains, the Southern Meade County Plains, and the
Sturgis/Piedmont Foot Hills. In Wyoming, Northeastern Crook
County, Northern Campbell County, Western Crook County, and
the Wyoming Black Hills.

* Through late tonight

* Saturated soils, very moist air, and additional thunderstorms
this afternoon and tonight may result in flash flooding.

* Any flooding that develops could wash out roads or culverts,
particularly in any low-lying areas, and affect property along
creeks, streams, and rivers.
properties.instruction:
A flash flood watch means that conditions are favorable for heavy
rain over the watch area, which may cause flash flooding along
streams, creeks, canyons, and draws. If you are in the watch
area, monitor NOAA weather radio and local media for updated
forecasts. Be ready to quickly move to higher ground, if heavy
rain occurs, rising water levels are observed, or a warning is
issued.

properties.areaDesc: Los Angeles County Coast including Downtown Los Angeles; Ventura County Coast; Catalina and Santa Barbara Islands
properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued July 3 at 12:42PM PDT until July 7 at 10:00PM PDT by NWS Los Angeles/Oxnard CA
properties.description:
* HAZARDS...Dangerous rip currents and breaking waves are expected
due to elevated surf of 3 to 6 feet with local sets to 7 ft. The
south swell is now forecast to persist into Sunday evening. This
statement has been updated to account for the extension through
that time.

* TIDES...High tides near 7 feet will occur each evening between 8
PM and 10 PM through Thursday. The evening tides will slowly
subside after Thursday.

* IMPACTS...There is an increased risk for ocean drowning. Rip
currents can pull swimmers and surfers out to sea. Large
breaking waves can wash people off beaches and rocks...and
capsize small boats near shore. Pooling of sea water is
possible around high tide at beach and harbor areas that is
uncommon with normal tidal ranges. Enhanced beach erosion is
also expected. No significant damage is expected.
properties.instruction:
A Beach Hazards Statement is issued when threats such as rip
currents...longshore currents...sneaker waves and other hazards
create life-threatening conditions in the surf zone. Swim near a
lifeguard. If caught in a rip current, relax and float. Don't
swim against the current. If able, swim in a direction following
the shoreline. If unable to escape, face the shore and call or
wave for help.

excess of 45 mph possible with these storms.

* Locations impacted include...
Chokoloskee, Everglades City, Golden Gate Estates, Plantation

Golde, Fakahatchee Strand State Preserve, Picayune Strand State

Miles City, Cape Romano Aquatic Preserve, Jerome and Deep Lake.
properties.instruction:

you can hear thunder, you are close enough to be struck! Seek a safe
shelter inside a building or vehicle.

agency. You can also share your report with NWS Miami on Facebook and
Twitter.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued July 3 at 3:33PM EDT by NWS Caribou ME
properties.description:
* The warm air temperatures this 4th of July weekend in the upper 80s
to around 90 may cause people to underestimate the dangers of the
cold water temperatures which are currently only in the upper 50s
and 60s on the lakes and in the lower 70s on the rivers.

* The cold water temperatures can quickly cause hypothermia to
anyone immersed in the water. According to the Maine Warden
Service, when the water temperature is below 60 degrees, the
average submerged person could lose dexterity within minutes and
be unable to accomplish simple tasks. Anyone on small boats,
canoes or kayaks should plan accordingly if recreating this
weekend and use extreme caution to avoid this threat. Paddle
smart from the start and always wear your life jacket!

NWSheadline: National Weather Service Cold Water Safety Message

properties.areaDesc: Bladen; Marion; Northern Horry; Williamsburg; Columbus; Central Horry; Inland Georgetown; Florence; Coastal Georgetown
properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued July 3 at 3:33PM EDT until July 3 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
properties.description:
* HEAT INDEX VALUES...Up to 107 due to temperatures in the mid
90s, and dewpoints in the mid 70s.

* TIMING...From 11 AM EDT this morning to 6 PM EDT early this
evening.

* IMPACTS...The heat and humidity may cause heat stress during
outdoor exertion or extended exposure.
properties.instruction:
A Heat Advisory means that a period of hot temperatures is
expected. The combination of high temperatures and humidity will
create a situation in which heat illnesses such as heat
exhaustion and worse yet, heat stroke, are possible.

If outdoors, drink plenty of fluids to stay well hydrated and
wear light weight and light colored clothing. It's also
recommended to take occasional to frequent rest breaks in shaded
or an air conditioned environment. In addition, be sure to check
on those who are most vulnerable to the heat such as young
children and the elderly.

Ensure all outdoor pets and livestock have access to fresh water
and a well ventilated and shaded area during the hottest portions
of the day. And never leave children or pets in a closed up
vehicle, temperatures could reach 120 degrees in a manner of
minutes.

properties.headline: Flash Flood Watch issued July 3 at 2:11PM CDT until July 4 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Des Moines IA
properties.description:
Thunderstorms will continue to develop across central Iowa this
afternoon and persist into the evening. The focal point for storms
will be between the Highway 20 and Interstate 80 corridor. This
region had areas with locally heavy rainfall over the past 24
hours. Locally heavy rainfall will once again be possible during
the watch period capable of producing significant ponding in urban
areas and possibly flash flooding.
The National Weather Service in Des Moines has issued a

* Flash Flood Watch for portions of central Iowa and west
central Iowa, including the following areas, in central Iowa,
Boone, Dallas, Hamilton, Jasper, Marshall, Polk, Poweshiek,
Story, Tama, and Webster. In west central Iowa, Audubon,
Calhoun, Carroll, Crawford, Greene, Guthrie, and Sac.

* Until 1 AM CDT Thursday

* Locally heavy rainfall of 2 to 4 inches is possible with
rainfall rates exceeding 2 inches per hour likely.

* Significant ponding in poor drainage and urban areas. Flash
flooding is also possible near small streams and due to overland
flooding.
properties.instruction:
A Flash Flood Watch means that conditions may develop that lead
to flash flooding. Flash flooding is a VERY DANGEROUS SITUATION.

You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action
should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.

properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued July 3 at 2:11PM CDT by NWS Corpus Christi TX
properties.description:
The combination of warm to hot temperatures and high dew point
temperatures will produce maximum heat index values between 105
and 109 degrees inclusive during the remainder of this afternoon
over the Coastal Bend. Conditions will improve this evening as
temperatures decrease.

Residents with outdoor activities planned are urged to drink
plenty of water, wear light weight and light colored clothing and
take frequent breaks from the heat. Young children and pets
should never be left unattended in vehicles under any
circumstances. This is especially true during warm or hot weather
when car interiors can reach lethal temperatures in a matter of
minutes.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued July 3 at 2:04PM CDT by NWS Tulsa OK
properties.description:
Arkansas River at Ozark Lock and Dam affecting Franklin...Johnson
and Logan Counties
The Flood Advisory continues for
The Arkansas River at Ozark Lock and Dam
* until further notice.
* At  1:00 PM Wednesday, the stage was 357.4 feet.
* Action stage is 355.5 feet.
* Flood stage is 357.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fluctuate between 355.5 feet
and 357.5 feet until further notice.
* Impact...At 357.0 feet, flooding affects agricultural use lands
along the river downstream of the lock and dam in Franklin County.
Gas fields are also subject to flooding downstream. Equipment and
livestock should be moved to higher ground. North 5th Street in
Logan County near the Six Mile Levee begins to flood and may cut
off access to a nearby residence.
* Impact...At 355.5 feet, the river remains in its banks, but access
to Okane Island may be cut off.

properties.description:
* LOCATION...Nome to Golovin

* WAVE AND SURF...2 to 4 feet above the normal high tide line.

* TIMING...Water levels peaked last evening around 4 feet above
the normal tide line in Nome. Water levels continue to slowly
fall along the coast but are expected to remain above the high
water line through early this evening as Southwest winds
continue to push water onshore.

* IMPACTS...Expect debris to continue to be pushed up on the beach
along with minor erosion. Residents are encouraged to move
property away from the shore. Expected high water levels on the
Snake River due to the heavy rain which will combine with the
high surf and elevated coastal water levels near the Port of
Nome and may produce minor flooding around the Port of Nome and
the Belmont subdivision.

properties.headline: Marine Weather Statement issued July 3 at 2:44PM EDT by NWS Miami FL
properties.description:

Lake Okeechobee...

At 244 PM EDT, Doppler radar indicated strong thunderstorms, capable
of producing winds to around 30 knots. These thunderstorms were
located along a line extending from 13 nm northeast of Buckhead Ridge
to 19 nm southeast of Pahokee, moving west at 10 knots.
properties.instruction:

waves, and lightning strikes. Boaters should seek safe harbor
immediately until these storms pass.

properties.areaDesc: Middlesex; Eastern Monmouth; Coastal Ocean; Western Monmouth; Ocean; Southeastern Burlington
properties.headline: Coastal Flood Advisory issued July 3 at 2:22PM EDT until July 4 at 1:00AM EDT by NWS Mount Holly NJ
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Mount Holly has issued a Coastal
Flood Advisory, which is in effect from 7:00 PM this evening until
1:00 AM Thursday.

* LOCATIONS...Coastal areas of Middlesex County, Monmouth County,
Ocean County and southeastern Burlington County.

* TIMING...High tide on the New Jersey oceanfront occurs between
8:30 PM and 9:30 PM this evening. High tide on the back bays and
on Raritan Bay occurs later than the high tide on the
oceanfront.

* COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Up to one half foot of saltwater
inundation above ground level is possible in low-lying areas
near shorelines and tidal waterways. Minor roadway flooding is
expected.

* WAVES...Wave heights on the ocean waters off the coast are
forecast to be around 2 feet.

* OUTLOOK...Another round of minor tidal flooding is expected on
Thursday evening.
properties.instruction:
A Coastal Flood Advisory means that minor tidal flooding is
expected. Minor tidal flooding often results in some road
closures. Usually, the most vulnerable roadways will flood.

Do not leave your vehicle at a location that is prone to tidal
flooding. Do not drive your vehicle through flood waters. The
water may be deeper than you think it is. You will be putting
yourself in danger and your vehicle may be damaged, leading to
costly repairs.

Visit the Advanced Hydrologic Prediction Service at
water.weather.gov/ahps for additional water level and flood impact
information for your local tide gauge.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued July 3 at 11:47AM CDT by NWS Bismarck ND
properties.description:
Missouri River near Williston affecting McKenzie and Williams
Counties
For the Missouri River Basin including Williston...Minor flooding is
occurring...With Moderate flooding forecast.

. Above normal rainfall along the Yellowstone and Missouri Rivers in
Montana continue to cause an up and down pattern in water levels
along the Missouri River near Williston. This relatively small amount
of extra runoff has delayed the inevitable fall back below flood
stage. The Missouri River near Williston will rise back above 24 feet
this week and remain there until around the middle of the second week
of July. Water levels for the Missouri River near Williston will
remain above flood stage until the latter part of July with normal
rainfall.
The Flood Warning continues for
The Missouri River near Williston.
* until further notice.
* At 10:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 23.9 feet.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Forecast...The river will continue rising to near 24.4 feet by
Saturday early afternoon then begin falling.
* Impact...At 24.0 feet...Water begins to cover oil well location
south and east of Williston. Wildlife management areas are flooded.
City of Williston does not flood.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...


Safety message...Do not drive into areas where water tops the
roadway. Turn around...Don't drown. Avoid driving on flooded roads.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued July 3 at 10:38AM MDT until July 8 at 11:00AM MDT by NWS Denver CO
properties.description:
Blue River below Dillon affecting Summit County.

Snowmelt runoff continues to cause the Blue River downstream of
Dillon Reservoir to overflow its banks. Low lying areas, including
yards and walkways next to the river, could flood in and downstream
of Silverthorne. Warm temperatures will continue to accelerate
high elevation runoff. This will cause the Blue River to remain
high through this weekend.
The Flood Advisory continues for
the Blue River below Dillon.
* until Monday morning.
* At 10:15 AM Wednesday the stage was 3.8 feet.
* Flood stage is 4.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will remain near 3.8 feet.
* Impact...At 3.7 feet...Water approaches yards in the South 40
Subdivision in northern Silverthorne and walkways along the Blue
River in Silverthorne.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Persons with interests along this river are urged to use caution.
Avoid flooded areas and stay clear of river banks that could become
unstable due to the high flows.

* At 10:00 AM Wednesday the stage was 7.8 feet.
* Moderate flooding is occurring and Moderate flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue remain near 7.8 feet this
afternoon. Additional rises may be possible thereafter.
* Impact...At stages near 7.0 feet...Buildings at the foot of Ann
Street on the river side of the flood wall will flood as water
overtops the Rio Oil Company dock. Buildings on the river side of
the Berwick floodwall will flood. River traffic restrictions will
be strictly enforced. In addition, backwater flooding could
potentially impact portions areas around Lake Palourde and
Stephensville.

be under water. Water will cover the lower end of Belleview Front
Street in Berwick. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger
river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly
enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 5.0 feet...Floodwall gates will be closed
to protect against higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected
by stronger river current and vessel traffic safety rules will be
strictly enforced by the U.S. Coast Guard.
* Impact...At stages near 4.0 feet...Action stage. Water will move
up the bank and across access roads below the city dock. Floodwall
gates should be closed by the 5 foot stage to protect against
higher stages. Vessel traffic will be affected by stronger river
current and vessel traffic safety rules will be strictly enforced
by the U.S. Coast Guard.

properties.headline: Flash Flood Watch issued July 3 at 12:19PM EDT until July 4 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Charleston WV
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Charleston has expanded the

* Flash Flood Watch to include portions of southeast Ohio and
West Virginia, including the following areas, in southeast
Ohio, Lawrence OH. In West Virginia, Cabell, Jackson WV,
Mason, and Putnam.

* Through Thursday evening.

* Much of the area has received 1 to 2 inches of rainfall over
the past 24 hours, saturating the soil. Additional thunderstorms
are forecast this afternoon and again Thursday, which could
lead to flash flooding.

* Flooding of urban and other poor drainage areas, as well as
creek and small stream flooding, is possible. People residing
near creeks and small streams should monitor the latest
forecasts, and prepare to take immediate action should
flooding occur, or if a flash flood warning is issued.
properties.instruction:
A Flash Flood Watch means that conditions may develop that lead
to flash flooding. Flash flooding is a very dangerous situation.

You should monitor later forecasts and be prepared to take action
should Flash Flood Warnings be issued.

NWSheadline: FLASH FLOOD WATCH IN EFFECT THROUGH THURSDAY EVENING

properties.headline: Coastal Flood Advisory issued July 3 at 12:02PM EDT until July 4 at 2:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington NC
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Wilmington has issued a Coastal
Flood Advisory, which is in effect from 9 PM this evening to 2 AM
EDT Thursday.

* LOCATIONS...The lower Cape Fear River including downtown
Wilmington.

* TIMING...From 9 PM this evening to 2 AM EDT Thursday.

* COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Water is six to 12 inches deep on the
lowest parts of Battleship Road and USS North Carolina Road.
Water begins to spread on to River Road about a quarter mile
south of The Cape Boulevard. In downtown Wilmington...water
covers more than a block of Water Street near Market Street
with three to six inches of water just south of Market Street.
properties.instruction:
A Coastal Flood Advisory indicates that onshore winds and tides
will combine to generate flooding of low areas along the shore.

NWSheadline: COASTAL FLOOD ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 9 PM THIS EVENING TO 2 AM EDT THURSDAY

properties.description:

Flood Advisory, which is in effect from 7 PM this evening to
midnight EDT tonight.

* LOCATIONS...Coastal Pender, Coastal New Hanover and Coastal
Brunswick.

* TIMING...From 7 PM this evening to midnight EDT tonight.

* COASTAL FLOOD IMPACTS...Minor street flooding occurs on the
sound-side of Carolina Beach, along Canal Drive from Starfish
Lane northward. Water gets into yards along the sound, but the
street flooding is mainly the result of salt water backing up
through the storm drains. Heavy rain at the time of high tide
exacerbates this problem.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued July 3 at 9:53AM MDT until July 6 at 1:15PM MDT by NWS Denver CO
properties.description:
Snowmelt runoff continues to cause the Colorado River in and near
Rocky Mountain National Park to overflow its banks. Low lying areas,
including a parking lot and trails, may be closed next to or
crossing the river. Warm temperatures will continue the accelerate
high elevation runoff. This will cause the headwaters of the
Colorado River in extreme northeast Grand County to remain high the
next several days.
properties.instruction:

of water in urban or other areas is occurring or is imminent.

near Dodge. Minor flooding is expected.

precipitation.

* Flood Warning for
The Trempealeau River at Dodge.
* from this evening to late Thursday night.
* At  9:45 AM Wednesday the stage was 10.3 feet.
* Flood stage is 10.5 feet.

properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...



If you live in a threatened area, be alert for high or rising water,
and be ready to move to higher ground if necessary.

Do not drive cars into flooded areas. Remember, it only takes two
feet of water to float most automobiles, including sport utility
vehicles. Turn Around, Don't Drown!

Stay tuned to your favorite source of weather information, including
NOAA Weather Radio, for later statements.

Additional river and weather information is available at...
http://www.weather.gov/lacrosse .

properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued July 3 at 11:28AM EDT until July 3 at 6:00PM EDT by NWS Raleigh NC
properties.description:
Heat index values will range from 105 to 107 for a few hours
this afternoon due the combination of temperatures near 100 and a
muggy air mass.
The National Weather Service in Raleigh has issued a Heat
Advisory, which is in effect until 6 PM EDT this evening.

* HEAT INDEX VALUES...will range from 105 to 107 for a few hours
this afternoon due the combination of temperatures near 100 and
a muggy air mass.

* TIMING...Heat index values will climb above 100 just after noon
and then range near or exceed 105 between 2 pm and 6pm.

* IMPACTS...The heat and humidity may cause heat stress during
outdoor exertion or extended exposure.
properties.instruction:
A heat advisory means that a period of hot temperatures is
expected. Hot temperatures and high humidity will create a
situation in which heat illnesses are possible. Drink plenty of
fluids, stay in an air-conditioned room, stay out of the sun, and
check up on relatives and neighbors.

If outdoors, drink plenty of fluids to stay well hydrated and
wear light weight and light colored clothing. It's also
recommended to take occasional to frequent rest breaks in
shaded or an air conditioned environment. In addition, be sure
to check on those who are most vulnerable to the heat such as
young children and the elderly.

NWSheadline: HEAT ADVISORY IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM EDT THIS EVENING

properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued July 3 at 9:10AM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO
properties.description:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has
issued the follow...

WHAT...Action Day for Ozone.

WHERE...El Paso, Douglas, Jefferson, Denver, Arapahoe, Adams,
Broomfield, Boulder, Larimer, Weld County.

WHEN...7/2/2019 4:00:00 PM MDT to 7/3/2019 4:00:00 PM MDT

ADDITION DETAILS...An Action Day for Ozone is now in effect for
the seven-county Denver- Boulder metropolitan area.  Requests to
limit driving are now in effect until at least 4 PM Wednesday,
July 3, 2019.  Ozone concentrations will remain in the Good to
Moderate range on Tuesday. However, limited chances for
thunderstorms, along with warmer temperatures and sunny skies,
will allow ozone to reach concentrations in the Unhealthy for
Sensitive Groups category on Wednesday. The highest concentrations
are expected from the south and west suburbs of Denver, northward
along the Front Range foothills, to the west of Ft. Collins.  For
areas included in this advisory that are not expected to exceed
the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups (USG) air quality designation,
we request that activities, such as driving, be reduced to lessen
the impacts on neighboring air quality. Additional air pollution
in this region may directly diminish air quality or contribute to
precursors which may also adversely affect air quality.  For
Colorado air quality conditions, forecasts and advisories, visit:
https://www.colorado.gov/airquality/colorado_summary.aspx

HEALTH INFORMATION...Increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms
and breathing discomfort in active children and adults and people
with lung disease, such as asthma. Active children and adults, and
people with lung disease, such as asthma, should reduce prolonged
or heavy outdoor exertion.

NWSheadline: ACTION DAY FOR OZONE 7/2/2019 4:00:00 PM MDT UNTIL 7/3/2019 4:00:00 PM MDT

properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Rainfall heavier than forecast could cause river levels to rise even
higher than predicted.  The National Weather Service will monitor
this developing situation and issue follow up statements as
conditions or forecasts change.

Safety message:  Never drive cars, trucks, or sport utility vehicles
through flooded areas.  The water may be too deep to allow for safe
passage.

This product, along with additional weather and stream information,
is available at http://water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=lsx.

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued July 3 at 9:57AM CDT until July 5 at 1:00PM CDT by NWS Twin Cities/Chanhassen MN
properties.description:
Cottonwood River at New Ulm affecting Brown County
Cottonwood River Above Springfield  affecting Brown County
Minnesota River at Montevideo affecting Chippewa...Lac qui Parle and
Yellow Medicine Counties
Minnesota River At New Ulm affecting Brown and Nicollet Counties
Redwood River near Redwood Falls affecting Redwood County
...The flood warning continues for the following rivers in
Minnesota..
Minnesota River At Morton  affecting Renville County

.Overview...The rainfall from this weekend continues to flow through
the rivers, with the quick responding streams already cresting while
the mainstem Minnesota remains swollen.  Further rainfall will keep us
in minor flooding a bit longer, especially if we would see another event
like this previous weekend.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Do not drive cars through flooded areas.  Turn Around...Don't Drown.

Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or your local radio or TV station
for the latest information concerning this flood event.

properties.headline: Small Craft Advisory issued July 3 at 7:57AM PDT until July 4 at 8:00AM PDT by NWS Seattle WA
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Seattle has issued a Small Craft
Advisory...which is in effect from 5 PM this afternoon to 8 AM
PDT Thursday.

* WIND AND WAVES...West winds 15 to 25 kt. Wind waves 2 to 4
feet.
properties.instruction:
A Small Craft Advisory means that wind speeds of 21 to 33 knots
are expected to produce hazardous wave conditions to small craft.
Inexperienced mariners, especially those operating smaller
vessels should avoid navigating in these conditions.

NWSheadline: SMALL CRAFT ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 5 PM THIS AFTERNOON TO 8 AM PDT THURSDAY

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued July 3 at 10:31AM EDT until July 5 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Northern Indiana
properties.description:
North Branch Elkhart River at Cosperville affecting Noble County

The North Branch Elkhart River at Cosperville remains elevated following
recent rounds of heavy rain and runoff. The river is forecast to remain
near minor flood stage through at least Thursday.
The Flood Warning has been extended for
The North Branch Elkhart River at Cosperville
* until Friday morning.
* At 9 AM Wednesday the stage was 6.1 feet and steady.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 6.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will fall below the 6.0 foot flood stage
around  2 AM Friday July  5.
* At 6.0 feet...Water approaches some houses around Skinner Lake,
especially along State Road 8.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Never drive vehicles through flooded areas. The water may be too deep
to allow safe passage. Never allow children to play in or near flood
waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather Radio or local media for further
statements and updated forecasts.

Detailed river forecasts and more information can be found on the
internet at www.weather.gov/iwx under Rivers and Lakes.

All times are in Eastern Time. This statement will be updated in
about 24 hours or sooner if necessary.

properties.areaDesc: Hidalgo, TX; Cameron, TX; Willacy, TX
properties.headline: Flood Warning issued July 3 at 9:28AM CDT until July 3 at 9:30PM CDT by NWS Brownsville TX
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Brownsville has extended the

* Flood Warning for...
East central Hidalgo County in Deep South Texas...
West central Cameron County in Deep South Texas...
Southwestern Willacy County in Deep South Texas...

* Until 930 PM CDT Wednesday.

* At 924 AM CDT, emergency management reported high water continuing
between Raymondville and Lasara along FM 490 and along FM 1425
between FM 490 and TX 186. Other locations continue to see
improvement with most roadways now open across Willacy county.
Water levels continue to recede in the Santa Rosa area, but
portions of FM 506 remain closed between La Feria and Santa Rosa.
Elsewhere, gradual improvement continues, but motorists are urged
to find an alternate route when encountering a flooded roadway.

* Some locations that will experience flooding include...
Santa Rosa, La Villa, Lasara, Yznaga, Tierra Bonita, Laguna Seca,
and Grand Acres.
properties.instruction:
Turn around, don't drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood
deaths occur in vehicles.

Keep children away from storm drains, culverts, creeks and streams.
Water levels can rise rapidly and sweep children away.

properties.areaDesc: Taiya Inlet and Klondike Highway; Haines Borough and Lynn Canal
properties.headline: Special Weather Statement issued July 3 at 6:18AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
properties.description:
Due to the recent warm weather, water levels on the Taiya and
Chilkat rivers are elevated. The Taiya River will likely peak at
bankfull levels during each evening before lowering some during
the morning. The Chilkat river will likely peak during the late
night hours, then bottom out during the late afternoon and early
evening. This pattern will continue through the week. Flooding is
not expected at this time. Anyone on or along these rivers should
monitor water levels closely.

NWSheadline: BANKFULL CONDITIONS LIKELY ON SOME AREA RIVERS

children to play in or near flood waters. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio or your local media for further statements and possible updated
forecasts.

Additional information is available at
http://www.crh.noaa.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=pah /lower case/

properties.description:

Osage River AT Taberville affecting St. Clair County

carry most vehicles away.

updates.

properties.headline: High Surf Advisory issued July 3 at 3:34AM HST until July 3 at 6:00PM HST by NWS Honolulu HI
properties.description:
The current long-period south-southwest swell will be reinforced
over the next several days. This will continue to produce
elevated surf near the advisory threshold along south facing
shores of all islands into the weekend. This advisory may need to
be extended if conditions warrant.
* SURF...5 to 8 feet along the south facing shores of Kauai and
Oahu, and 6 to 10 feet along the south facing shores of Maui
County and the Big Island.

* TIMING...Through this afternoon.

* IMPACTS...Moderate...Expect strong breaking waves, shore
break, and strong longshore and rip currents making swimming
difficult and dangerous.
properties.instruction:
Beachgoers, swimmers, and surfers should heed all advice given by
ocean safety officials and exercise caution. Boaters should
expect recreational surfers and body boarders utilizing harbor
channels to access surfing areas.

NWSheadline: HIGH SURF ADVISORY REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 6 PM HST THIS EVENING

properties.areaDesc: San Diego County Coastal Areas; Orange County Coastal
properties.headline: Beach Hazards Statement issued July 3 at 5:51AM PDT until July 5 at 3:00AM PDT by NWS San Diego CA
properties.description:
* Waves and Surf...A long period southwest swell will generate
above average surf of 3 to 6 feet on Orange and San Diego
County beaches.

* Impacts...Minor tidal overflow at beaches and harbors that are
most prone to flooding from tidal runup. This includes Seal
Beach and Sunset Beach in Orange County, and Cardiff Beach and
Imperial Beach in San Diego County. High tides near 6.7 feet
will occur each evening between 9 PM and Midnight.

* Rip Currents...Increased risk of strong rip currents that can
pull swimmers out to sea.
properties.instruction:
A beach hazards statement is issued when threats such as strong
rip currents...elevated surf heights...minor tidal overflow...or
lightning are possible at local beaches. Obey posted warning
signs and flags and talk to a lifeguard before swimming.

properties.headline: Dense Smoke Advisory issued July 3 at 4:14AM AKDT until July 4 at 1:00PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage, AK
properties.description:
* LOCATION...Interior Kenai Peninsula, including the Sterling
Highway corridor from Sterling to Cooper Landing.

* SMOKE...Smoke from the Swan Lake fire will reduce visibilities
to one quarter mile or less at times. The worst conditions
will be overnight through the morning hours, with improvement
during the afternoon and evening.

* TIMING...Through Thursday, though there is potential for dense
smoke to persist through the weekend.

* IMPACTS...Travel may be difficult due to low visibility.
Persons with respiratory problems may have difficulty
breathing when outside. For more information on Air Quality,
please visit www.dec.alaska.gov.
properties.instruction:
A dense smoke advisory means widespread fires will create smoke,
limiting visibilities. If driving, slow down, use your
headlights, and leave plenty of distance ahead of you in case a
sudden stop is needed. For the latest road conditions call
5 1 1 or visit 511.alaska.gov.

properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued July 3 at 4:52AM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg SC
properties.description:
The South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control in
Columbia SC has issued a Code Orange Ground Level Ozone Action Day
for the Catawba region of South Carolina, from 10 AM this morning to
8 PM EDT this evening.

An ozone action day means that atmospheric conditions will likely
produce unhealthy concentrations of ground level ozone air
pollution. A Code Orange forecast indicates that ground level ozone
concentrations are expected to be unhealthy for sensitive groups,
which includes people with lung disease, older adults and children.
Sensitive groups should reduce prolonged or heavy outdoor exertion,
take more breaks, and do less intense activities, especially during
afternoon and early evening hours. You can help prevent ozone
pollution by carpooling, walking or riding your bicycle, taking your
lunch to work, reducing idling, conserving energy, and keeping your
vehicle properly tuned. For additional information, please visit the
South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control web
site at http://www.scdhec.gov/ozone or the Environmental Protection
Agency AirNow website at https://www.airnow.gov.

properties.areaDesc: Southern Lake County; Okeechobee; Inland Volusia; Orange; Northern Brevard County; Osceola; Northern Lake County; Coastal Volusia; Seminole
properties.headline: Heat Advisory issued July 3 at 4:34AM EDT until July 3 at 7:00PM EDT by NWS Melbourne FL
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Melbourne has issued a Heat
Advisory, which is in effect from 11 AM this morning to 7 PM EDT
this evening.

* TEMPERATURE...Heat index values between 106 and 110 are expected
across the interior today, as well as along the coastal Volusia
County and north Brevard County.

* IMPACTS...The high heat index values could lead to dehydration,
heat exhaustion, and heat stroke for those outdoors.
properties.instruction:
A Heat Advisory means that a period of hot temperatures is
expected. The combination of hot temperatures and high humidity
will combine to create a situation in which heat illnesses are
possible. Drink plenty of fluids...stay in an air-conditioned
room...stay out of the sun...and check up on relatives and
neighbors.

Take extra precautions...if you work or spend time outside. When
possible...reschedule strenuous activities to early morning or
evening. Know the signs and symptoms of heat exhaustion and heat
stroke. Wear light weight and loose fitting clothing when possible
and drink plenty of water.

To reduce risk during outdoor work...the occupational safety and
health administration recommends scheduling frequent rest breaks
in shaded or air conditioned environments. Anyone overcome by heat
should be moved to a cool and shaded location. Heat stroke is an
emergency...call 9 1 1.

NWSheadline: HEAT ADVISORY IN EFFECT FROM 11 AM THIS MORNING TO 7 PM EDT THIS EVENING

properties.headline: Red Flag Warning issued July 3 at 2:22AM MDT until July 4 at 8:00PM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
properties.description:
..RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON TO 8 PM MDT THURSDAY, THE
FOURTH OF JULY, FOR WIND, LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY AND DRY FUELS FOR
NORTHWEST COLORADO FIRE WEATHER ZONES 200 AND 202 AND EASTERN
UTAH FIRE WEATHER ZONE 490 BELOW 5000 FEET...

.Gusty southwest winds will combine with low relative humidity
and dry fuels today and Thursday during the afternoon and evening
hours. This will result in critical fire weather conditions for
portions of east-central Utah and northwest Colorado both days.
The overnight hours will see humidities recover as well as
decreasing winds.
...RED FLAG WARNING IN EFFECT FROM NOON TO 8 PM MDT THURSDAY, THE
FOURTH OF JULY, FOR WIND, LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY AND DRY FUELS FOR
FIRE WEATHER ZONES 200 AND 202...

The National Weather Service in Grand Junction has issued a Red
Flag Warning for wind, low relative humidity and dry fuels, which
is in effect from noon to 8 PM MDT Thursday. The Fire Weather
Watch is no longer in effect.

* AFFECTED AREA...In Colorado, Fire Weather Zone 200 Little
Snake Forecast Area and Fire Weather Zone 202 White River
Forecast Area.

* WINDS...Southwest 15 to 25 mph with gusts up to 35 mph.

* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...9 to 14 percent.

* IMPACTS...Conditions will be favorable for the rapid ignition,
growth, and spread of fires. Agricultural burning is strongly
discouraged.
properties.instruction:
A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions
are either occurring now, or will shortly. A combination of
strong winds, low relative humidity, and warm temperatures can
contribute to extreme fire behavior.

NWSheadline: RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT FROM NOON TODAY TO 8 PM MDT THIS EVENING FOR WIND, LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY AND DRY FUELS FOR FIRE WEATHER ZONES 200 AND 202

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued July 2 at 8:13PM CDT until July 21 at 7:00AM CDT by NWS New Orleans LA
properties.description:
Mississippi River At Red River Landing affecting East Baton
Rouge...Pointe Coupee and West Feliciana Parishes

Mississippi River At Baton Rouge affecting East Baton Rouge and
West Baton Rouge Parishes

Mississippi River At Donaldsonville affecting Ascension Parish

Mississippi River At Reserve affecting St. Charles...St. James and
St. John The Baptist Parishes
The Flood Warning continues for
The Mississippi River At Reserve.
* Until Sunday July 21.
* At  7:00 PM Tuesday the stage was 22.5 feet.
* Minor flooding is occurring and Minor flooding is forecast.
* Flood stage is 22.0 feet.
* Forecast...The river will continue to fall to below flood stage by
Sunday July 21.
* Impact...At 22.0 feet...Marine and industrial interests along the
river, upstream barge operators, and facilities are impacted.
Navigation will become difficult for smaller river craft. Safety
precautions for river traffic are urged.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

around the Veterinary Medicine building, the Veterinary Medicine
Annex, the stadium and ball fields. The city of Baton Rouge and the
main LSU campus are protected by levees at this level.
* Impact...At 38.0 feet...River traffic and industrial activity on the
river side of the levees will be greatly affected. Navigational
safety regulations will be strictly enforced.
properties.instruction:
PRECAUTIONARY/PREPAREDNESS ACTIONS...

Forecast crests are based upon rainfall that has occurred along with
anticipated rain for the next 24 hours. Adjustments to the forecasts
will be made if additional heavy rainfall occurs.

Do not drive cars through flooded areas. Remember, two feet of
rushing water can carry away most vehicles including pickups.  Turn
around and don't drown!

A followup product will be issued later. Stay tuned to NOAA Weather
Radio, local tv and radio stations...or your cable provider, for the
latest information. The latest graphical hydrologic information can
also be found at Weather.Gov.

properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued July 2 at 5:10PM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO
properties.description:
The Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment has
issued the following...

WHAT...Action Day for Ozone.

WHERE...El Paso, Douglas, Jefferson, Denver, Arapahoe, Adams,
Broomfield, Boulder, Larimer and Weld counties.

WHEN...7/2/2019 4:00:00 PM MDT to 7/3/2019 4:00:00 PM MDT

ADDITION DETAILS...An Action Day for Ozone is now in effect for the
seven-county Denver-Boulder metropolitan area.  Requests to limit
driving are now in effect until at least 4 PM Wednesday, July 3,
2019.  Ozone concentrations will remain in the Good to Moderate
range on Tuesday. However, limited chances for thunderstorms, along
with warmer temperatures and sunny skies, will allow ozone to reach
concentrations that are Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups on Wednesday.
The highest concentrations are expected in the western portions of
the northern Colorado Front Range. For more information, please see
the Air Quality Forecast below. For areas included in this advisory
that are not expected to exceed the Unhealthy for Sensitive Groups
(USG) air quality designation, we request that activities, such as
driving, be reduced to lessen the impacts on neighboring air quality.
Additional air pollution in this region may directly diminish air
quality or contribute to precursors which may also adversely
affect air quality.  For Colorado air quality conditions,
forecasts and advisories, visit:
https://www.colorado.gov/airquality/colorado_summary.aspx

HEALTH INFORMATION...Increasing likelihood of respiratory symptoms
and breathing discomfort in active children and adults and people
with lung disease, such as asthma. Active children and adults, and
people with lung disease, such as asthma, should reduce prolonged
or heavy outdoor exertion.

NWSheadline: ACTION DAY FOR OZONE 7/2/2019 4:00:00 PM MDT UNTIL 7/3/2019 4:00:00 PM MDT

The Maryland Department of the Environment has issued a Code
ORANGE Air Quality Alert Wednesday for
the Baltimore metro area.

A Code Orange Air Quality Alert means that air pollution
concentrations within the region may become unhealthy for
sensitive groups. Sensitive groups include children, people
suffering from asthma, heart disease or other lung diseases and
the elderly. The effects of air pollution can be minimized by
avoiding strenuous activity or exercise outdoors.

For more information on ground-level ozone and fine
particles... visit www.mde.state.md.us/air or call 410-537-3000.

properties.instruction:

temperatures and increased debris.

homepage at weather.gov/gjt

properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued July 2 at 3:48PM EDT by NWS Columbia SC
properties.description:
The South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control
has issued an Air Quality Action Day...in effect from 10 AM to 8 PM
Wednesday July Third.

A Code Orange Air Quality Alert for ozone has been issued for the
Central Midlands Region. An ozone action day means that atmospheric
conditions will likely produce unhealthy concentrations of ground
level ozone air pollution. A Code Orange forecast indicates that
ground level ozone concentrations are expected to be unhealthy
for sensitive groups, which includes people with lung disease,
older adults and children. Sensitive groups should reduce
prolonged or heavy outdoor exertion, take more breaks, and do
less intense activities, especially during afternoon and early
evening hours. You can help prevent ozone pollution by carpooling,
walking or riding your bicycle, taking your lunch to work,
reducing idling, conserving energy, and keeping your vehicle
properly tuned. For additional information, please visit the
South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control
web site at http://www.scdhec.gov/ozone or the Environmental
Protection Agency AirNow website at https://www.airnow.gov.

properties.areaDesc: Wayne; St. Clair; Washtenaw; Lenawee; Oakland; Monroe; Macomb
properties.headline: Air Quality Alert issued July 2 at 1:07PM EDT by NWS Detroit/Pontiac MI
properties.description:
The Michigan Department of Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy has
declared Wednesday July 3th to be an action day for elevated levels
of ozone. Pollutants are expected to be in the unhealthy for
sensitive groups range.

The action day is in effect for the following Michigan counties...

St. Clair...Oakland...Macomb...Washtenaw...Wayne...Lenawee and
Monroe.

People and businesses are urged to avoid activities which lead to
ozone formation. These activities include refueling vehicles or
topping off when refueling, using gasoline-powered lawn equipment
and using charcoal lighter fluid. Positive activities include car
pooling, biking to work, delaying or combining errands and using
water-based paints.

It is recommended that active children and adults, and people with
respiratory diseases such as asthma, limit prolonged outdoor
exertion.

For further information, please see the Michigan Department of
Environment, Great Lakes, and Energy page at http://www.deqmiair.org

properties.headline: Flood Warning issued July 1 at 2:44PM AKDT until July 3 at 4:15PM AKDT by NWS Anchorage AK
properties.description:
The National Weather Service in Anchorage has extended the

* Flood Warning for...
Snowmelt in...YENTNA RIVER NEAR FISH CREEK

* Until 415 PM AKDT Wednesday.

* At 244 PM AKDT, Snow and glacial melt in the Yentna Basin have
caused river levels along the lower Yentna River below Fish Creek
to rise above Flood Stage. River levels are expected to rise
another half a foot into moderate flood stage early Tuesday
morning. At this time, locations adjacent to the river and
downstream of Lake Creek are expected to have water in them. Also,
low lying areas adjacent to the river are flooded. River levels
are expected to remain in Flood conditions until July 5.

Residents along this part of the river should prepare for river
levels to continue rising another half a foot.

properties.headline: Flood Advisory issued July 1 at 12:27PM MDT until July 4 at 1:15PM MDT by NWS Grand Junction CO
properties.description:
Elevated flows along the Los Pinos River in eastern La Plata County
can be expected until further notice. Runoff above the dam is
occurring as warm temperatures have accelerated the melting of the
high elevation snowpack. Elevated releases below Vallecito Dam are
necessary to mitigate this incoming water. These warm temperatures
and possible rainfall will keep runoff high through the week.
properties.instruction:
Excessive runoff from snow melt will cause creeks, streams and
rivers to rise. Minor flooding along the banks and in low lying
areas will be possible.
